newsitem.title: UK: Licht sees world, U.S. HFS output rising in 1996/9.
newsitem.headline: Licht sees world, U.S. HFS output rising in 1996/9.

text.p: World production of high fructose syrup (HFS) is expected to rise to 10.24 million tonnes dry basis in 1996/97 from 9.82 million in 1995/96, analyst F.O. Licht said on Thursday.
The United States, the world's leading HFS producer, would turn out 7.58 million tonnes in 1996/97, compared with 7.36 million the previous year.

In the latest edition of its International Sugar and Sweetener Report, Licht said HFS production advanced by 22.3 percent from 1992/93 to 1996/97, compared with the 11.7 percent seen in the sugar sector.
But the solid growth rate could not conceal the fact that U.S. manufacturers were having a hard time after years of prosperity and success, it said.
"Despite growing three percent in 1996/97, the industry is in deep trouble," the Licht report said.
"Once the star performer of the U.S. food industry, HFS production has lost its shine for many players and the industry is about to enter a decisive restructuring phase."
Licht said Japan, the third largest HFS producer worldwide, would turn out 798,000 tonnes in 1996/97 and just up from the 789,000 reported for the previous year.
It added that the Asian HFS market seemed to have reached a high level of saturation in many countries of the region after a very promising start in the mid-1980s.
HFS output in Asia's three leading producers -- Japan, South Korea and Taiwan -- had remained at a high level without stirring too much excitement, it said.
Mexican HFS production was expected to rise sharply, and output was pegged at 120,000 tonnes after just 25,000 in 1995/96.
In the European Union, where output was effectively constrained by production quotas, HFS production was expected to rise to 302,863 tonnes in 1996/97 from 297,766 in 1995/96.
Licht said HFS production was also making good progress in central and eastern Europe, noting new projects announced in Slovakia, Turkey and Russia.
"Although small by U.S. standards, the new operations could mean increased competition for sucrose in the highly lucrative market for liquid sweeteners," it said.
"Given rapid growth for soft drink consumption in the region, the outlook for HFS production is rather favourable."
Hungary was one of the region's leading HFS producers and output would rise to 130,000 tonnes from 117,000.
